Package Datastructures.Theory.EquivalenceClasses

Class EquivalenceClass

java.lang.Object
Datastructures.Theory.EquivalenceClasses.EquivalenceClass
public class EquivalenceClass extends Object
This class represents an equivalence class of literals. Equivalence classes can come from the input clauses. They also can be derived, for example from two-literal clauses, for example: p,q and -p,-q. A class can be extended, when new equivalences are derived, for example: p=q=r and r=s yields p=q=r=s. The equivalence class selects one literal as representative. Initially the smallest predicate is selected as representative. The representative remains fixed, even if further equivalences with smaller predicates are added.

  • Field Details

    • representative

      public int representative
      the representative of the equivalence class.

    • literals

      public it.unimi.dsi.fastutil.ints.IntArrayList literals
      the literals which are equivalent to the representative.

    • inferenceSteps

      public ArrayList<InferenceSteps.InferenceStep> inferenceSteps
      null or the inference steps which produced the equivalence. The literals-array and the inferenceSteps array are kept synchronized.

  • Constructor Details

    • EquivalenceClass

      public EquivalenceClass(int representative, it.unimi.dsi.fastutil.ints.IntArrayList literals, ArrayList<InferenceSteps.InferenceStep> inferenceSteps)
      creates an equivalence class. A new equivalence class is not directly created here from an inputClause because it must be analysed first and may turn out to be superfluous.
      Parameters:
      representative - the representative of the class.
      literals - the list of equivalent literals.
      inferenceSteps - null or the list of inference steps for the equivalence class.

  • Method Details

    • clone

      public EquivalenceClass clone()
      clones the equivalence class.
      Overrides:
      clone in class Object
      Returns:
      a clone of the equivalence class.

    • makeEquivalenceClass

      public static EquivalenceClass makeEquivalenceClass(int[] inputClause, Datastructures.Theory.Model model, boolean trackReasoning) throws Datastructures.Results.Unsatisfiable
      analyses an input clause of type EQUIV and generates an equivalence class.
      Parameters:
      inputClause - an input clause (maybe redundant or contradictory)
      model - the global model
      trackReasoning - if true then inference steps are added
      Returns:
      null or a new equivalence class.
      Throws:
      Datastructures.Results.Unsatisfiable - if the class is contradictory (p == -p)

    • isAlreadyTrueInModel

      protected static boolean isAlreadyTrueInModel(int[] inputClause, Datastructures.Theory.Model model, boolean trackReasoning) throws Datastructures.Results.Unsatisfiable
      each literal in an equivalence which is true/false in the model causes the equivalent literals to become true/false. It is very unlikely that this happens. Just to be on the safe side.
      Parameters:
      inputClause - an equivalence clause
      model - the model
      trackReasoning - true if the inferences are to be tracked
      Returns:
      true if the equivalent literals all became true/false and the clause can be ignored.
      Throws:
      Datastructures.Results.Unsatisfiable - if a contradiction was discovered.

    • containsLiteral

      public int containsLiteral(int literal)
      checks if the equivalence class contains the literal.
      Parameters:
      literal - a literal.
      Returns:
      +1 if the literal is with the same sign, -1 if it is with opposite sign, 0 if it is not contained in the class.

    • overlaps

      public int overlaps(EquivalenceClass eqClass)
      checks if the other equivalence class overlaps with this class.
      Parameters:
      eqClass - another equivalence class
      Returns:
      +1 if there is a positive overlap, -1 if there is a negative overlap, 0 if there is no overlap.

    • addNewEquivalence

      public void addNewEquivalence(int oldLiteral, int newLiteral, InferenceSteps.InferenceStep newInferenceStep, ArrayList<Utilities.TriConsumer<Integer,Integer,InferenceSteps.InferenceStep>> observers) throws Datastructures.Results.Unsatisfiable
      adds a new equivalence to the equivalence class. There must be a newly derived equivalence oldLiteral == newLiteral where oldLiteral is already in the class, (with the right sign). In this case the newLiteral is added to the class.
      Parameters:
      oldLiteral - a literal which is already contained in the equivalence class.
      newLiteral - a new equivalent literal.
      newInferenceStep - which derived the equivalence oldLiteral = newLiteral.
      Throws:
      Datastructures.Results.Unsatisfiable - if the newLiteral is already in the class.

    • getInferenceStep

      public InferenceSteps.InferenceStep getInferenceStep(int literal)
      finds the inference step that caused representative = literal
      Parameters:
      literal - a literal in the literals
      Returns:
      null or the inferenceStep that caused representative = literal

    • joinOverlappingClasses

      public EquivalenceClass joinOverlappingClasses(EquivalenceClass eqClass, int sign) throws Datastructures.Results.Unsatisfiable
      joins two overlapping clauses from the input into one equivalence class
      Parameters:
      eqClass - the equivalence class to be joined
      sign - +1 or -1
      Returns:
      a new equivalence class
      Throws:
      Datastructures.Results.Unsatisfiable - if the two classes contain contradictory literals.

    • joinEquivalenceClass

      public EquivalenceClass joinEquivalenceClass(EquivalenceClass eqClass, int literal1, int literal2, int sign, InferenceSteps.InferenceStep inferenceStep, ArrayList<Utilities.TriConsumer<Integer,Integer,InferenceSteps.InferenceStep>> observers)
      joins the given equivalence class into 'this' Example: this = p,q,r and eqClass = a,b,c
      Because r = c, (see inference step) the resulting class is p,q,r,a,b,c We choose as surviving class the class with the smallest representative.
      Parameters:
      eqClass - the class to be joined.
      literal1 - a literal in this.
      literal2 - a literal in eqClass.
      sign - +1 or -1, the sign for the second class.
      inferenceStep - which caused the equivalence of literal1 == literal2.
      observers - for noticing the new equivalences.
      Returns:
      the new joined class.

    • applyTrueLiteral

      protected void applyTrueLiteral(int trueLiteral, int sign, InferenceSteps.InferenceStep trueInferenceStep, Datastructures.Theory.Model model) throws Datastructures.Results.Unsatisfiable
      If a literal has turned out to be true/false then all other literals in the class must also be true/false.
      Parameters:
      trueLiteral - a literal which has become true.
      sign - +1 if all literals are to become true, -1 if they are to become false.
      trueInferenceStep - which caused the truth of the literal
      model - the global model
      Throws:
      Datastructures.Results.Unsatisfiable - if a contradiction is encountered.

    • toString

      public String toString(Datastructures.Symboltable symboltable)
      returns the equivalence class as a string 'representative = literal1 = ...' If the symboltable is provided, it will be used.
      Parameters:
      symboltable - null or a symboltable.
      Returns:
      the equivalence class as a string 'representative = literal1 = ...'

    • toString

      public String toString()
      returns the equivalence class as a string 'representative = literal1 = ...' without a symboltable.
      Overrides:
      toString in class Object
      Returns:
      the equivalence class as a string 'representative = literal1 = ...'
